thread.title: Are Rochester-area schools ignoring bullying?

author: democratandchronicle.com
title: Are Rochester-area schools ignoring bullying?
text:
In 2012, the New York State Education Department began requiring all public schools to file reports on incidents of bullying, harassment, intimidation or menacing, an effort to shine a light on an age-old problem. That light has shone more brightly some places than others. Two years after the reporting requirements went into effect, 42 Rochester-area schools in 14 districts told the state they had zero such incidents in the 2013-14 school year.
Some of the schools have a reputation for well-behaved students, including those in Brighton, Fairport, Penfield and Pittsford. But even a generally serene student body would be hard-pressed to pass an entire school year without one material incident of harassment of any kind.
Amanda Nickerson, director of the Alberti Center for Bullying Abuse Prevention at the University of Buffalo, said student surveys show that one in three children report being involved in bullying one way or another. Even more report being involved in some sort of harassment.
“From what we know from multiple studies, bullying and harassment are common and it is nearly impossible for a school to have no incidents in an entire school year,” she said.
“From what we know from multiple studies, bullying and harassment are common and it is nearly impossible for a school to have no incidents in an entire school year.”
Amanda Nickerson, director of the Alberti Center for Bullying Abuse Prevention at the University of Buffalo Reportable behavior is defined under the law, in part, as: “conduct ... that has or would have the effect of unreasonably and substantially interfering with a student's educational performance, opportunities or benefits, or mental, emotional or physical well-being.”
Of the 42 schools with no confirmed, reported incidents, 36 are elementary schools. The others are Twelve Corners Middle School in Brighton, Spry Middle School in Webster, Minerva Deland School in Fairport, Rochester Early College International High School and two charter schools, University Prep Charter School for Young Men and Rochester Career Mentoring Charter School.
There are two distinct but similar categories in which schools are supposed to report such offenses.
One is the Dignity for All Students Act, (DASA), which specifically gathers bullying and harassment incidents. The other, which has been in place longer, is the Violent and Disruptive Incident Report (VADIR), which has several sub-categories, including one for “intimidation, menacing, harassment or bullying,” either with or without a weapon.

State to survey schools on anti-bullying efforts
The 42 schools, with a combined student body of more than 20,000, listed no incidents in either category.
All the districts involved either confirmed that there were, in fact, no reportable incidents in 2013-14 or did not respond to a request for comment.
When asked whether the state education department believes the data it receives from schools is accurate, spokeswoman Jeanne Beattie pointed to a series of training sessions the state is providing on the subject and said that “NYSED continues to work with districts to ensure that VADIR and DASA data is reported accurately.”
A report earlier this year by the state comptroller surveyed seven secondary schools from across the state, including East High School in Rochester, and found 935 unreported incidents under VADIR across all its categories in one school year.
Besides those schools with zero bullying incidents, many reported only a handful, even at the middle school or high school levels.
Penfield High School, for instance, reported just three incidents under VADIR and none under DASA. Fairport High School reported one under VADIR and two under DASA.
Willink, one of Webster’s two middle schools, reported 28 incidents, while the other, Spry, reported zero. Both have about 1,000 students.
Since the numbers vary so widely, it is impossible to know whether a school with many reported incidents truly has more incidents or is just more diligent in its reporting.
The secondary schools with the most reported DASA and VADIR bullying incidents are mostly in the Rochester School District, with East High School leading the way by an order of magnitude.
The DASA data is also broken down by the topic of bullying. There again, Monroe County children either showed remarkable civility or had their offenses go unreported.
For instance, there were only 29 reported instances of bullying related to weight across all the school districts in the county, which have a combined enrollment near 110,000.
There were 63 bullying incidents related to race, color or ethnicity; 75 related to gender or sex; 22 related to disability; and 39 related to sexual orientation. The lion’s share — 89 percent of the 2,248 total offenses — were marked down as “other.”
Besides its reporting requirements, DASA also includes a framework of proactive training and intervention sessions that schools are supposed to follow. Nickerson said compliance there seems to be better.
She suspected reporting is sometimes low either because schools are confused about the requirements or because they fear being identified as unsafe.
“It’s just sort of a crime count, so I’m sure some schools don’t want it to be a poor reflection of what they’re doing,” she said. “If another school is reporting zero and they were going to report 42 cases, that might make them pause. ... But (with better reporting) there would be an open acknowledgment that this is an issue and they’re taking it seriously.”
